author: Special Correspondent
text:
The Consumer Protection Council, Tamil Nadu on Wednesday urged the district authorities to shift the children studying in Carmel English School at Ramalinga Nagar in the city to other CBSE schools.

Alleging that the school had admitted children from Classes 1 to 9 without getting affiliation from Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE), S. Pushpavanam, secretary of the council, said the future of the children were at stake.

The school had gone ahead with admissions in spite of warning by the CBSE, he said.

He told presspersons here that the CBSE had rejected the online application of Carmel English School seeking affiliation twice for failing to furnish documentary evidences for change of name from the State Education Department and others.

The CBSE had stated that the school had not furnished recognition for up to Class 8 in favour of Carmel English School from the State Education Department.

He said he had taken up the issue with the Collector seeking his intervention to shift the affected children to other CBSE schools.

Efforts on: school

Packia Jothi Devadoss, Correspondent, Carmel English School, said the management had been making sincere efforts to get CBSE affiliation. The board had raised a few queries on a few aspects.

The school was under the process of getting affiliation soon. The future of the children would not be affected, he maintained.
title: Consumer body objects to admissions by private school
